keyTakeAways: Los Angeles District Attorney George Gascón recommended resentencing for Lyle and Erik Menendez, who were convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, in 1989.

The recommendation is based on new evidence of physical and sexual abuse by their father, particularly highlighted in a 2023 habeas corpus petition involving a sworn statement by former Menudo member Roy Rosselló and a letter from Erik Menendez.

Under California law, the brothers may now be eligible for life with the possibility of parole due to having committed the crimes when they were under 26 years old, and they are considered rehabilitated.

Gascón emphasized that the brothers have been model prisoners, contributing to prison rehabilitation programs and self-improvement, and that societal views on abuse and justice have evolved since the original trial.

The decision follows a broader trend in sentencing reform, including over 300 resentencings in the county since 2020, and is supported by public figures such as Kim Kardashian and family members of the victims.

The case has gained renewed attention due to the Netflix series 'Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story' and associated documentaries, which have amplified public discourse about abuse, justice, and rehabilitation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Los Angeles District Attorney George Gascón has recommended that a judge resentence Lyle and Erik Menendez, who were convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents in 1989, citing new evidence of abuse by their father and a shift in societal understanding of trauma and justice. The brothers, who have served life without parole for nearly 30 years, are now eligible for life with the possibility of parole under California law due to their age at the time of the crime and demonstrated rehabilitation. The decision follows a 2023 habeas corpus petition that presented new evidence, including a sworn statement from Roy Rosselló alleging sexual abuse by Jose Menendez and a letter from Erik Menendez referencing abuse. Public figures such as Kim Kardashian and family members have praised the move as a necessary step toward justice. The case has gained renewed attention due to the Netflix series and documentary, which have highlighted the brothers' claims of abuse and their post-prison contributions. A hearing is expected within 30 to 45 days, with the final decision resting with a Los Angeles Superior Court judge.
title: Los Angeles District Attorney Recommends Resentencing in Decades-Old Menendez Brothers Murder Case
